{{Chabad (Rebbes and Chasidim)|Shluchim}} '''Yitzchok Moully''' is an [[Australian]]-[[Americans|American]], [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] rabbi and artist associated with the [[Chabad|Chabad-Lubavitch]] [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidic]] movement and is known for his "Chasidic Pop Art" painting style. Moully serves as a Chabad emissary (''[[Shaliach (Chabad)|shaliach]]'') in [[Basking Ridge, New Jersey]].<ref name=mishpop>Bensoussan, Barbara. "True Color." ''Mishpacha Magazine''. July 4, 2012.</ref><ref name=mishpop1>[http://www.collive.com/show_news.rtx?id=20827&alias=pop-artist-chossid-shliach "Pop Artist, Chossid, Shliach."] ''COLlive.com''. July 8, 2012.</ref><ref name=algepop>[http://www.algemeiner.com/author/yitzchak-moully/ "Yitzchok Moully."] ''The Algemeiner Journal''. Accessed December 1, 2014.</ref>
Moully's combination of rabbinic work and art is expressed in a piece "Orange Socks." The piece, according to Moully, contrasts what people think of as a homogeneous Chassidic experience.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wischusen |first1=Phreddy |title=‘Under the Black Hat’ Pop Art in Jerusalem Focuses on Chassidim - Rabbi Yitzchok Moully brings spiritual and emotional depth to a new exhibit |url=https://www.chabad.org/news/article_cdo/aid/3824604/jewish/Under-the-Black-Hat-Pop-Art-in-Jerusalem-Focuses-on-Chassidim.htm |website=www.chabad.org |accessdate=October 29, 2018 |language=en |date=October 24, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Yitzchok Moully was born in 1979<ref name=forpop/> in [[Queensland, Australia]] but moved to [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] at the age of three. At the age of five, Moully and his mother moved to [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn]] and joined the Chabad community there. Moully later studied at Chabad yeshivoth, married, and became the assistant rabbi at the Chabad Jewish Center of Basking Ridge, New Jersey.<ref name=mishpop/>
==Art== Moully has produced works by using the silkscreen process; his art contrasts strong Jewish and Chasidic images with vibrant bold colors creating what he describes as "Chassidic Pop Art."<ref name=algepop/> Moully uses color and styles similar to the work of [[Andy Warhol]], using popular images from Jewish Chasidic culture including [[dreidels]], [[Kiddush]] cups and praying rabbis.<ref name=forpop>Trappler-Spielman, Sara. [http://www.forward.com/articles/12739/hasidic-rabbi-by-day-pop-artist-by-night-/ Hasidic Rabbi by Day, Pop Artist by Night."] ''The Jewish Daily Forward''. Wednesday, February 20, 2008.</ref> Moully also works in abstract art, and has been heavily influenced by artists such as by the French Canadian artist Jean Pierre Lafrance <ref>Peter Kharmandarian [http://www.artonthebanks.com/2015/05/interviews-the-pop-art-rabbi-yitzchok-moully/ Interview: The Pop Art Rabbi – Yitzchok Moully]</ref>
In 2006, Moully began exhibiting his art in galleries and community centers in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania. Currently, his work is on exhibit at the gallery [[ArtisZen Arts]] in [[Lambertville, New Jersey]].<ref name=forpop/>
==The Creative Soul== Moully founded a network of Orthodox Jewish artists called "The Creative Soul."<ref name=mishpop/><ref>Trappler-Spielman, Sara. [http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-arts-and-culture/music/136445/baal-teshuva-arts-brooklyn "Sick of Dancing Hasidim Playing Violins? Meet the New Baal Teshuvah Artists of Brooklyn."] ''Tablet Magazine''. July 1, 2013.</ref><ref>Bressler, Yaakov. [http://www.thejewishweek.com/blogs/well-versed/supporting-israel-art "Supporting Israel With Art."] September 19, 2014. ''The New York Jewish Week''.</ref> The group has sought to bring together local Chasidic artists, responding to the community's need for a greater focus on creativity.<ref>Trappler-Spielman, Sara. [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303380004579520331784835804 "A Safe Space for Jewish Artists: The Creative Soul Opens in Brooklyn."] ''The Wall Street Journal''. April 28, 2014.</ref> The Creative Soul has organized an annual exhibition in Crown Heights during the Jewish holiday of [[Sukkot]]. The exhibition has included submissions from local Chabad artists including Yitzchok Moully and [[Michoel Muchnik]]<ref>[http://www.crownheights.info/psa/47250/chassidic-artists-to-participate-in-group-art-show/ "Chassidic artists to participate in group art show."] ''CrownHeights.info''. September 27, 2012.</ref>
